name: Intolerance of Uncertainty
description: A tendency to react negatively to uncertain situations, often manifesting as excessive worry about the unknown.
insightTemplate: Across your entries, words related to uncertainty appeared in {hitCount} out of {totalEntries} entries. This repeated focus may resemble what psychology calls 'Intolerance of Uncertainty' (Carleton, 2012) — a tendency to find uncertain situations particularly stressful.
whyExplanation: This insight was generated because the following keywords appeared repeatedly across multiple journal entries: {matchedKeywords}. The frequency of these words ({frequency}) suggests a recurring theme of uncertainty in your reflections.

name: Self-Compassion
description: The practice of treating oneself with kindness and understanding during difficult times, rather than harsh self-judgment.
insightTemplate: Across your entries, words related to self-criticism appeared in {hitCount} out of {totalEntries} entries. This pattern may connect to what Dr. Kristin Neff calls 'Self-Compassion' (Neff, 2003) — specifically, the absence of it, where harsh self-judgment replaces self-kindness.
whyExplanation: This insight was generated because the following keywords appeared repeatedly across multiple journal entries: {matchedKeywords}. The frequency of these words ({frequency}) suggests a pattern of self-critical language in your writing.

name: Growth Mindset
description: The belief that abilities and intelligence can be developed through effort, learning, and persistence.
insightTemplate: Across your entries, words related to growth and learning appeared in {hitCount} out of {totalEntries} entries. This may reflect what Carol Dweck describes as a 'Growth Mindset' (Dweck, 2006) — a belief that your abilities can be developed through dedication.
whyExplanation: This insight was generated because the following keywords appeared repeatedly across multiple journal entries: {matchedKeywords}. The frequency of these words ({frequency}) suggests an orientation toward learning and self-improvement in your reflections.

name: Rumination
description: A pattern of repeatedly thinking about the causes, consequences, and symptoms of negative feelings without taking action to address them.
insightTemplate: Across your entries, words related to repetitive thinking appeared in {hitCount} out of {totalEntries} entries. This pattern may align with what psychologist Susan Nolen-Hoeksema describes as 'Rumination' (1991) — a cycle of dwelling on negative thoughts.
whyExplanation: This insight was generated because the following keywords appeared repeatedly across multiple journal entries: {matchedKeywords}. The frequency of these words ({frequency}) suggests a recurring theme of repetitive, cyclical thinking in your reflections.

name: Gratitude Orientation
description: A general tendency to recognize and respond with grateful emotion to the roles of other people's benevolence.
insightTemplate: Across your entries, words related to gratitude appeared in {hitCount} out of {totalEntries} entries. This pattern may reflect what Emmons & McCullough call 'Gratitude Orientation' (2003) — a tendency to notice and appreciate positive aspects of life.
whyExplanation: This insight was generated because the following keywords appeared repeatedly across multiple journal entries: {matchedKeywords}. The frequency of these words ({frequency}) suggests a recurring theme of appreciation and thankfulness in your reflections.
